title: Korn Ferry
text: Korn Ferry is a management consulting firm headquartered in Los Angeles, California.

title: Korn Ferry
text: It was founded in 1969 and as of 2019, operates in 104 offices in 52 countries and employs 8,678 people worldwide.

title: Korn Ferry
text: Korn Ferry trades through three business segments: Korn Ferry Executive Search, Korn Ferry Advisory and Korn Ferry RPO and Professional Search.

title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
text: The annual PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament, also known as Qualifying School or Q-School, was historically the main method by which golfers earned PGA Tour playing privileges, commonly known as a Tour card.

title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
text: Beginning in 2013, Q-School grants privileges only for the Korn Ferry Tour, the PGA Tour's official developmental circuit.

title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
text: The first tournament was played in 1965.

title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
text: In several early years (1968–69, 1975–81), two separate tournaments were played, one in the spring and one in the fall.

title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
text: The format of the tournament has changed several times, ranging from a 72-hole tournament to a 144-hole tournament.

title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
text: The current format (in place since 1982) is 108 holes over six days in late November and early December.

title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
text: Before 2013, the top 25 players and ties earned their tour cards.

title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
text: The next set of fifty finishers earned full Korn Ferry Tour cards.

title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
text: The remaining participants received conditional Korn Ferry Tour status.

title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
text: The 2012 Qualifying Tournament was the last to grant playing privileges for the PGA Tour.

title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
text: On March 20, 2012, the tour announced radical changes to its season structure and qualifying process, and announced further details on July 10 of that year.

title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
text: The 2013 season ended with The Tour Championship in September, and the 2014 season began the following month.

title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
text: Since then, the Qualifying Tournament only grants playing privileges for the Korn Ferry Tour (known as the Nationwide Tour at the time of the March 2012 announcement).

title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
text: A new series of three tournaments known as the Korn Ferry Tour Finals, held in September, grants 50 PGA Tour cards to a field consisting of the top 75 on the Korn Ferry Tour money list and the golfers placed 126 to 200 on the PGA Tour's FedEx Cup points list.

title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
text: The top 25 on the Korn Ferry Tour money list before the Finals receive PGA Tour cards, with total money earned in the Finals determining the remaining 25 card earners.

title: WinCo Foods Portland Open
text: The WinCo Foods Portland Open is a golf tournament on the Korn Ferry Tour.

title: WinCo Foods Portland Open
text: It was first played in August 2014 at Witch Hollow at Pumpkin Ridge in North Plains, Oregon, a suburb of Portland.

title: WinCo Foods Portland Open
text: Northwest-based supermarket chain WinCo Foods was named as the title sponsor in June 2013.

title: WinCo Foods Portland Open
text: Since its inception, the Portland Open has become the last regular season event on the Korn Ferry Tour.

title: WinCo Foods Portland Open
text: The event gives players one last chance to place in the Top 25 on the money list to earn a PGA Tour card or play their way into the top 75 to retain full Korn Ferry Tour privileges and earn a chance at a PGA Tour card via the Korn Ferry Tour Finals.

title: Korn Ferry Tour Championship
text: The Korn Ferry Tour Championship presented by United Leasing & Finance is the year-end golf tournament of the Korn Ferry Tour.

title: Korn Ferry Tour Championship
text: It has been played at a variety of courses; starting in 2019 it will be played at Victoria National Golf Club in Newburgh, Indiana as part of a 10 year deal.

title: Korn Ferry Tour Championship
text: Since the 2008 edition, the purse has been $1,000,000, with the winner receiving $180,000.

title: Korn Ferry Tour Championship
text: The format of the tournament is stroke play at 18 holes for four days, a total of 72 holes.

title: Korn Ferry Tour Championship
text: Originally, the field consisted of the top 60 players on the money list, all attempting to be among the 25 to earn PGA Tour cards.

title: Korn Ferry Tour Championship
text: Since 2013, it has been part of the Korn Ferry Tour Finals and the field consists of the top 75 players from the Korn Ferry Tour money list and the non-exempt players ranked 126 to 200 on the PGA Tour's money list at the start of the Finals.

title: Korn Ferry Tour Championship
text: Beginning in 2013, 50 PGA Tour cards will be awarded after the event.

title: Korn Ferry Tour Championship
text: It is considered the flagship event of the Korn Ferry Tour, with twenty OWGR points to the winner, compared to sixteen for other Finals events and fourteen for regular season tournaments.

title: Eleanor of Toledo
text: Eleanor of Toledo

title: Eleanor of Toledo
text: ( Italian:" Eleonora di Toledo"( 11 January 1519 – 17 December 1562), born Doña Leonor Álvarez de Toledo y Osorio, was a Spanish noblewoman who was the wife of Cosimo I de' Medici and the Duchess of Florence.

title: Eleanor of Toledo
text: Although Eleanor is often referred to as the Grand Duchess of Tuscany, she predeceased the creation of the Grand Duchy of Tuscany.

title: Eleanor of Toledo
text: She is credited with being the first modern first lady, or consort.

title: Eleanor of Toledo
text: She served as regent of Florence during the absence of her spouse.

title: Katatau
text: Eberti Marques de Toledo( born March 1, 1986) is a Brazilian football player.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: Don Pietro de' Medici( 3 June 1554 – 25 April 1604) was the youngest son of Cosimo I de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany and Eleonora di Toledo.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: Early in 1571 he went to Rome and in the spring of 1575 he went to Venice.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: In 1571 he married his first cousin Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo, whom he accused of adultery and strangled with a dog leash in July 1576 at the Villa Medici at Cafaggiolo.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: He also had her supposed lover Bernardino Antinori imprisoned and killed.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: At the end of 1577, he went for the first of many stays at the Spanish court.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: He remained in Spain until the end of 1578.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: During this visit he gained a reputation as a spendthrift and a rake.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: He left Tuscany in October 1579 to bring Italian troops to Spain and lead them during the mission to Portugal.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: He stayed in Lisbon until the end of 1582 when he returned to Spain where his presence is documented in 1583 and 1584.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: His correspondence proves that he had serious money problems.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: He came to Italy in July 1584 to ask his brothers to cover his debts, incurring their disapproval for living with a woman with a questionable reputation.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: The Medici court tried to arrange a marriage for Pietro.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: In July 1586 he went back to Spain, where he continued to accumulate debts.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: He came back to Italy in November 1587 after Francesco I de' Medici's death and stayed until September 1589, when he went back to Spain.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: His marriage to Dona Beatriz de Lara, daughter of Manuel de Menezes, the Portuguese Duke of Vila Real, in 1593 did little to stabilize him economically and emotionally.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: Pietro continued to see his lover Antonia de Carvajal who gave him five children out of wedlock.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: He also had an illegitimate son with Maria della Ribera.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: He kept writing to his brother Ferdinando I de' Medici, asking for a portion of the family fortune to cover his debts.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: In 1596 he came to Italy to appeal in vain to the Pope to side with him in the controversy.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: Pietro died, deeply in debt, before turning 50.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: After his death his illegitimate children were all brought to Florence to be cared for by the Medici.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: Pietro was buried in the Monasterio de la Santissima Trinidad in Madrid.

title: Pietro de' Medici
text: His corpse was later brought to Florence by Cosimo II de' Medici.

title: Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo
text: Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo or Leonor Álvarez de Toledo Osorio

title: Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo
text: (March 1553 – 10 July 1576), more often known as "Leonora" or "Dianora", was the daughter of García Álvarez de Toledo, 4th Marquis of Villafranca, Duke of Fernandina.

title: Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo
text: Leonora was born in Florence, where she was brought up by

title: Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo
text: Cosimo I de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany and his wife Eleanor of Toledo, her aunt and namesake.

title: Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo
text: Betrothed to their son Pietro at the age of 15, she blossomed under the wing of Pietro's older sister, the artistic patron Isabella, into a vivacious and witty beauty.

title: Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo
text: Her marriage, like Isabella's, was not a success, and she followed her mentor's example of taking lovers.

title: Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo
text: For this reason, Pietro had her brought in 1576 to the country retreat of Cafaggiolo, where he strangled her to death with a dog leash.

title: Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo
text: Cosimo's successor, Francesco I, tacitly approved the murder, and Pietro was never brought to justice for it.

title: Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo
text: Until recently, little was known of Leonora di Garzia di Toledo, and she was not identified as the sitter of several portraits of her.

title: Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo
text: The facts of her life have emerged from the growing scholarship on Isabella de' Medici, with whom she has much in common.

title: Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo
text: In the view of art historian Gabrielle Langdon, "Her story is valuable in revealing attitudes and legalities attendant on the lives and decorum of women in the early-modern Italian court".

title: Obata Toramori

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Etan Boritzer( born 1950) is an American writer of children ’s literature who is best known for his book" What is God?" first published in 1989.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: His best selling" What is?" illustrated children's book series on character education and difficult subjects for children is a popular teaching guide for parents, teachers and child- life professionals.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer gained national critical acclaim after" What is God?" was published in 1989 although the book has caused controversy from religious fundamentalists for its universalist views.

title: Etan Boritzer

title: Etan Boritzer

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is a Feeling?"

text: The series is now also translated into 15 languages.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer was first published in 1963 at the age of 13 when he wrote an essay in his English class at Wade Junior High School in the Bronx, New York on the assassination of John F. Kennedy.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: His essay was included in a special anthology by New York City public school children compiled and published by the New York City Department of Education.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer now lives in Venice, California and maintains his publishing office there also.

title: Etan Boritzer

title: James Alday
text: James Alday( 1516–1576?) was a 16th- century English navigator, explorer and privateer.

title: James Alday
text: He participated in raids against the Spanish with fellow privateers James Logan and William Cooke during the 1540s and is credited, along with Sebastian Cabot and Henry Ostrich, of the start of regular trading between England and the Barbary coast.

title: James Alday
text: He himself claimed to have organised the earliest known voyage to the Barbary coast inventing the Barbary trade and, although intending to command the expedition himself, Alday was forced to turn his command to another due to illness.

title: James Alday
text: This voyage was not successful however and a rival expedition commanded by Thomas Windham became the first to arrive there in 1551.

title: James Alday
text: His claim has generally been dismissed partly due to his involvement in piracy as well as lack of evidence.

title: Shear strength (discontinuity)
text: The shear strength of a discontinuity in a soil or rock mass may have a strong impact on the mechanical behavior of a soil or rock mass.

title: Shear strength (discontinuity)
text: The shear strength of a discontinuity is often considerably lower than the shear strength of the blocks of intact material in between the discontinuities, and therefore influences, for example, tunnel, foundation, or slope engineering, but also the stability of natural slopes.

title: Shear strength (discontinuity)
text: Many slopes, natural and man-made, fail due to a low shear strength of discontinuities in the soil or rock mass in the slope.

title: Shear strength (discontinuity)
text: The deformation characteristics of a soil or rock mass are also influenced by the shear strength of the discontinuities.

title: Shear strength (discontinuity)
text: For example, the modulus of deformation is reduced, and the deformation becomes plastic( i.e. non-reversible deformation on reduction of stress) rather than elastic( i.e. reversible deformation).

title: Shear strength (discontinuity)
text: This may cause, for example, larger settlement of foundations, which is also permanent even if the load is only temporary.

title: Shear strength (discontinuity)
text: Furthermore, the shear strength of discontinuities influences the stress distribution in a soil or rock mass.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: Gideon Johnson Pillow (June 8, 1806 – October 8, 1878) was an American lawyer, politician, speculator, slaveowner, United States Army major general of volunteers during the Mexican–American War and Confederate brigadier general in the American Civil War.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: Before his military career, Pillow practiced law and was active in Democratic Party politics.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: He was a floor leader in support of the nomination of fellow-Tennessean James K. Polk at the 1844 Democratic National Convention.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: In 1847, Pillow was commissioned a brigadier general of volunteers to serve in the Mexican–American War, and was later promoted to major general.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: He performed reasonably well, and was wounded that year at Cerro Gordo and Chapultepec.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: However, controversy arose when, in a series of letters, Pillow tried to take what was perceived by some as undue credit for American victories at the expense of his commander, Major General Winfield Scott.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: Pillow was court-martialed for insubordination, but with President Polk's assistance, the court-martial was reduced to a court of inquiry, which in 1848 exonerated Pillow.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: After the war, Pillow served as a delegate to the Nashville Convention of 1850, where he supported compromise.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: He remained active in supporting the Democratic Party.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: At the start of the Civil War in 1861, Pillow supported secession, and was commissioned a brigadier general in the Confederate Army in July.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: Pillow received the thanks of the Confederate Congress for driving off the Union force at the Battle of Belmont, Missouri.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: Pillow controversially failed to exploit a temporary break through of Union lines by his troops which might have allowed the Confederate garrison of Fort Donelson to escape at the Battle of Fort Donelson on February 15, 1862.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: The next night, before the surrender of the fort, Brigadier General John B. Floyd passed overall command of the fort to Pillow, who in turn passed it to Brigadier General Simon Buckner.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: Floyd and Pillow managed to personally escape with a few aides before Buckner surrendered the remaining garrison to the Union Army of Brigadier General Ulysses S. Grant.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: These actions sent his military career and reputation into decline.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: Pillow commanded a brigade at the Battle of Stones River in 1863, where he performed poorly, and was among the few generals in the army to praise the leadership of commanding General Braxton Bragg.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: Removed from combat duty, he worked mainly in recruiting assignments through the remainder of the war.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: Bankrupt after the war, Pillow recovered financially and resumed a successful legal career.

title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
text: He died near Helena, Arkansas in 1878; initially buried in Helena, Pillow was later reinterred at Elmwood Cemetery in Memphis.

title: Holm Jølsen

title: Holm Jølsen

title: Holm Jølsen

title: Holm Jølsen
text: In 1887 he established Enebak Cellulosefabrik, which was one of the first pulp mills in Norway.

title: Holm Jølsen

title: Richard N. Palmer
text: Following law school, Palmer clerked for Judge Jon O. Newman, then of the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut.

title: Richard N. Palmer
text: After practicing privately with Shipman and Goodman, Palmer was as an Assistant United States Attorney in the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of Connecticut, interrupted briefly by a stint in the firm of Chatigny and Palmer.

title: The Beginning or the End
text: The Beginning or the End is a 1947 American docudrama film about the development of the atomic bomb in World War II, directed by Norman Taurog, starring Brian Donlevy and Hume Cronyn, and released by Metro- Goldwyn- Mayer.

title: The Beginning or the End
text: The film dramatizes the creation of the atomic bomb in the Manhattan Project and the bombing of Hiroshima.

title: The Beginning or the End
text: The film originated in October 1945 as a project of actress Donna Reed and her high school science teacher, Edward R. Tompkins, who was a chemist at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

title: The Beginning or the End
text: Bob Considine wrote the treatment, which was sent to MGM script writers.

title: The Beginning or the End
text: The title was supplied by President Harry S. Truman.

title: The Beginning or the End
text: At the time there was a legal requirement that permission be obtained to depict living well- known public figures.

title: The Beginning or the End
text: Many refused, but others, such as J. Robert Oppenheimer, co-operated.

title: The Beginning or the End
text: Major General Leslie R. Groves, Jr., the director of the Manhattan Project, was hired as a consultant for$ 10,000.

title: The Beginning or the End
text: Although the filmmakers put considerable effort into historical accuracy, particularly in details, the film is known for some key distortions of history.

title: The Beginning or the End
text: An entirely fictional sequence was added in which Truman agonizes over whether to authorize the attack; anti-aircraft shells are shown bursting around the" Enola Gay" on its bombing run over Hiroshima; and it is said that leaflets were dropped on Hiroshima for ten days in advance of the mission warning the citizens of the forthcoming raid.

title: The Beginning or the End
text: The film received generally mixed reviews, and was a box office disappointment.

title: George I of Greece
text: George I (Greek:

title: George I of Greece
text: Γεώργιος Α ́, Geórgios I; 24 December 1845 – 18 March 1913) was King of Greece from 1863 until his assassination in 1913.

title: George I of Greece
text: Originally a Danish prince, he was born in Copenhagen, and seemed destined for a career in the Royal Danish Navy.

title: George I of Greece
text: He was only 17 years old when he was elected king by the Greek National Assembly, which had deposed the unpopular former king Otto.

title: George I of Greece
text: His nomination was both suggested and supported by the Great Powers: the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, the Second French Empire and the Russian Empire.

title: George I of Greece
text: He married the Russian grand duchess Olga Constantinovna of Russia in 1867, and became the first monarch of a new Greek dynasty.

title: George I of Greece
text: Two of his sisters, Alexandra and Dagmar, married into the British and Russian royal families.

title: George I of Greece
text: King Edward VII and Tsar Alexander III were his brothers-in-law, and King George V, Tsar Nicholas II, King Christian X of Denmark and King Haakon VII of Norway were his nephews.

title: George I of Greece
text: George's reign of almost 50 years (the longest in modern Greek history) was characterized by territorial gains as Greece established its place in pre-World War

title: George I of Greece
text: I Europe.

title: George I of Greece
text: Britain ceded the Ionian Islands peacefully in 1864, while Thessaly was annexed from the Ottoman Empire after the Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878).

title: George I of Greece
text: Greece was not always successful in its territorial ambitions; it was defeated in the Greco-Turkish War (1897).

title: George I of Greece
text: During the First Balkan War, after Greek troops had captured much of Greek Macedonia, George was assassinated in Thessaloniki.

title: George I of Greece
text: Compared with his own long tenure, the reigns of his successors Constantine, Alexander, and George II proved short and insecure.

title: Prince Christopher of Greece and Denmark
text: Prince Christopher of Greece and Denmark (10 August 1888 – 21 January 1940) was the fifth and youngest son and youngest child of King George I of Greece, belonging to a dynasty which mounted and lost the throne of Greece several times during his lifetime.

title: Prince Christopher of Greece and Denmark
text: Much of his life was spent living abroad.

title: Andrée Lafayette

title: Andrée Lafayette
text: She was the lover of Prince Andrew of Greece and Denmark.

title: Brian Kennedy (gallery director)

title: Brian Kennedy (gallery director)
text: He is currently the director of the Peabody Essex Museum.

title: Brian Kennedy (gallery director)
text: He was the director of the Toledo Museum of Art in Ohio from 2010 to 2019.

title: Brian Kennedy (gallery director)

title: Guilty of Treason
text: Guilty of Treason is a 1950 American drama film directed by Felix E. Feist and starring Charles Bickford, Bonita Granville and Paul Kelly.

title: Guilty of Treason
text: Also known by the alternative title Treason, it is an anti-communist and anti-Soviet film about the story of József Mindszenty, a Roman Catholic cardinal from Hungary.

title: Guilty of Treason
text: Mindszenty spoke out against the Nazi occupation of his country during World War II, as well as the later Communist regime.

title: Guilty of Treason
text: Because of his opposition to the Soviet regime, Mindszenty was arrested and tortured.

title: Guilty of Treason
text: After his release, he took refuge in the US Embassy in Budapest for many years, maintaining his support for the Hungarians who wanted an end to the Russian occupation.

text: Ian Barry is an Australian director of film and TV.

text: By marriage she became Duchess of Norfolk.

title: Elizabeth Stafford, Duchess of Norfolk
text: Her abusive marriage to Thomas Howard, 3rd Duke of Norfolk, created a public scandal.

title: Lord Bernard Stewart
text: Lord Bernard Stewart( 1623 – 26 September 1645) was a Scottish aristocrat who served as a Royalist commander in the English Civil War.

title: Lord Bernard Stewart
text: He was the youngest of the five sons of Esmé Stewart, 3rd Duke of Lennox, and his wife Katherine Clifton, 2nd Baroness Clifton, and the brother of James Stewart, 1st Duke of Richmond.

title: Lord Bernard Stewart
text: Lord Bernard was to be created Earl of Lichfield by King Charles I for his actions at the first and second battles of Newbury and Naseby but died of injuries received leading a sortie against besieging Parliamentary forces in the Battle of Rowton Heath in September 1645, before the patent could be implemented.

title: Lord Bernard Stewart
text: The titles of Baron Newbury and Earl of Lichfield were instead created in December 1645 for his six- year- old nephew, Charles Stewart( 1639 – 1672), the son of Bernard's elder brother George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny, who had been killed at the Battle of Edgehill in 1642.

title: Lord Bernard Stewart
text: His brother John was also killed in the war.

title: Jacobo Fitz-James Stuart, 3rd Duke of Berwick
text: Jacobo Francisco Eduardo Fitz- James Stuart y Colón de Portugal, 3rd Duke of Berwick, 3rd Duke of Liria and Jérica, 9th Duke of Veragua, 9th Duke of la Vega( 28 December 1718 – Valencia, 30 September 1785) was a Spanish Jacobite.

title: Jacobo Fitz-James Stuart, 3rd Duke of Berwick
text: On the death of his father, James Fitz- James Stuart, in 1738, he inherited his titles of Duke of Berwick and Duke of Liria and Xerica( he also possessed many other titles in both Spain and England.)

title: Jacobo Fitz-James Stuart, 3rd Duke of Berwick
text: His mother was Spanish, and on her side he was a direct descendant of explorer Christopher Columbus.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: George Stewart (or Stuart), 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny (17 July 1618 – 23 October 1642) was a Scottish nobleman and Royalist commander in the English Civil War.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: He was the son of Esmé Stewart, 3rd Duke of Lennox, and his wife Katherine Clifton, 2nd Baroness Clifton, and the brother of James Stewart, 1st Duke of Richmond and 4th Duke of Lennox, and of the Royalist commander Lord Bernard Stewart.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: Stewart, his older brother Henry, and younger brother Ludovic were brought up at Aubigny in France as Roman Catholics under the charge of their paternal grandmother, the old Duchess-Dowager, Katherine de Balsac.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: Stewart's father, the Duke of Lennox, died in 1624, and Stewart became a ward of his cousin, King Charles I of England.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: He inherited the Lordship of Aubigny at the age of 14 on the death of his elder brother Henry in 1632.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: By 1633, he was a student at the Collège de Navarre, part of the University of Paris, and he did homage to Louis XIII of France for the lordship of Aubigny on 5 August 1636, shortly after his eighteenth birthday.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: Later that year he moved to England.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: In 1638 he secretly married Katherine Howard, the daughter of Theophilus Howard, 2nd Earl of Suffolk, and Elizabeth Home, without her father's consent, offending his guardian the king.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: The portrait of Stewart by Anthony van Dyck, now in the National Portrait Gallery, London, may have been painted to mark his marriage; the Latin inscription can be translated

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: "Love is stronger than I am" which may allude to his conflicting loyalties.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: His younger brothers Lords John and Bernard are shown in a still more famous double Van Dyck portrait in the National Gallery, London - the iconic image of Cavaliers.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: They were also both killed in the Civil War. George Stewart and Katherine Howard had two children:

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: He fought with the French against the Spanish in the Battle of Montjuïc (1641).

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: As civil war loomed in England, Stewart joined the forces of King Charles at York where he was knighted on 18 April 1642 along with his brother Bernard.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: He was mortally wounded in the first pitched battle of the war at Edgehill on Sunday 23 October 1642, aged 24.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: He was buried in Christ Church Cathedral, Oxford.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: The lordship of Aubigny passed to his next brother, Ludovic, on his death.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: His widow remarried James Levingston, 1st Earl of Newburgh and had one further child Elizabeth.

title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
text: They were suspected in 1648 of plotting to rescue Charles I and on the discovery of the supposed plot fled to the Netherlands where Katherine died in 1650.

title: Charles Lennox, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: Field Marshal Charles Lennox, 3rd Duke of Richmond, 3rd Duke of Lennox, 3rd Duke of Aubigny,( 22 February 1735 – 29 December 1806), styled Earl of March until 1750, was a British Army officer and politician.

title: Charles Lennox, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: He associated with the Rockingham Whigs and rose to hold the post of Southern Secretary for a brief period.

title: Charles Lennox, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: He was noteworthy for his support for the colonists during the American Revolutionary War, his support for a policy of concession in Ireland and his advanced views on the issue of parliamentary reform.

title: Charles Lennox, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: He went on to be a reforming Master- General of the Ordnance first in the Rockingham ministry and then in the ministry of William Pitt.

title: Lord John Stewart
text: Lord John Stewart( 23 October 1621 – 29 March 1644) was a Scottish aristocrat who served as a Royalist commander in the English Civil War.

title: Lord John Stewart
text: He was one of five sons of Esmé Stewart, 3rd Duke of Lennox and his wife Katherine Clifton, 2nd Baroness Clifton, and the brother of James Stewart, 1st Duke of Richmond.

title: Lord John Stewart
text: With his youngest brother, Lord Bernard Stewart, he embarked on a three- year tour of the continent in 1639, before returning to join the King ’s cause in the Civil War as a General.

title: Lord John Stewart
text: He was killed at the Battle of Cheriton near Alresford, Essex, on 29 March 1644.

title: Lord John Stewart
text: Only one of his brothers, Lodovic, survived the war to see the restoration of the monarchy in 1660.

title: James Hamilton, 6th Duke of Hamilton
text: James George Hamilton, 6th Duke of Hamilton and 3rd Duke of Brandon, KT( 10 July 1724 – 17 January 1758) was a Scottish peer.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond, 6th Duke of Lennox KG (7 March 1639December 1672) was the only son of George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny and Katherine Howard, daughter of Theophilus Howard, 2nd Earl of Suffolk.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: He was the grandson of Esmé Stewart, 3rd Duke of Lennox.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: On 10 December 1645 he was created Baron Stuart of Newbury, Berkshire, and Earl of Lichfield, titles conferred on him "to perpetuate the titles which were intended to have been conferred on his uncle" Lord Bernard Stewart, youngest son of the Duke of Lennox, who had been killed in the Battle of Rowton Heath in the English Civil War in September of that year.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: In January 1658, Charles Stewart went into exile in France, and took up his residence in the house of his uncle, Ludovic, seigneur d'Aubigny.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: In the following year he fell under the displeasure of The Protectorate's Council of State, and warrants were issued for seizing his person and goods.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: Charles Stewart married, firstly, Elizabeth Rogers, after June 1659.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: He married, secondly, Margaret Banaster (widow of William Lewis) on 31 March 1662.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: He married, thirdly, Frances Teresa Stewart, granddaughter of Walter Stewart, 1st Lord Blantyre, in March 1667.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: This last marriage was famous, as Frances Stewart, known at court as "Le Belle Stuart" had been desired by Richmond's cousin, King Charles II, as a mistress.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: Charles Stewart returned to England with Charles II in 1660, and sat in the Convention Parliament, showing great animosity towards the supporters of the Commonwealth.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: On the death of his 10-year-old cousin Esmé Stewart on 10 August 1660, Charles Stewart succeeded as third Duke of Richmond and sixth Duke of Lennox.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: In that same year he was created Hereditary Great Chamberlain of Scotland, Hereditary Great Admiral of Scotland, and Lord-Lieutenant of Dorset.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: On 15 April 1661 he was invested with the Order of the Garter.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: On the death of his uncle, Ludovic Stuart, he succeeded him as 12th Seigneur D'Aubigny, for which title he did homage by proxy to Louis XIV of France on 11 May 1670.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: In July 1667, on the death of his cousin, Mary Butler, countess of Arran, he became Baron Clifton, and on 4 May 1668 he was made lord lieutenant and vice admiral of Kent jointly with the Earl of Winchilsea.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: In 1671 he was sent as ambassador to the Danish court to persuade Denmark to join England and France in a projected attack on the Dutch.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: While there he died (by drowning) in 1672, aged 33 at Elsinore, without issue, and his titles became extinct, with the exception of Baron Clifton, which passed with most of his property to his sister Katherine, Lady O'Brien.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: His wife, however, had had the Lennox estates granted to her for life.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: He was buried on 20 September 1673 at Westminster Abbey.

title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
text: The titles Duke of Richmond, Duke of Lennox and Earl of March, were resurrected for Charles II's illegitimate son by Louise de Kérouaille, Charles Lennox, 1st Duke of Richmond and Lennox, in 1675.

title: James Stewart, 1st Duke of Richmond
text: James Stewart, 1st Duke of Richmond, 4th Duke of Lennox KG

title: James Stewart, 1st Duke of Richmond
text: ( 6 April 1612 – 30 March 1655) was a British nobleman.

title: James Stewart, 1st Duke of Richmond
text: He was the eldest son of Esmé Stewart, 3rd Duke of Lennox and his wife Katherine Clifton, 2nd Baroness Clifton.

title: James Stewart, 1st Duke of Richmond
text: James Stewart inherited the Dukedom of Lennox on his father's death( 30 June 1624) and was made a gentleman of the bedchamber in 1625, and knighted on 29 June 1630.

title: James Stewart, 1st Duke of Richmond
text: He was invested as a knight of Order of the Garter in 1633.

title: James Stewart, 1st Duke of Richmond
text: He married Mary Villiers, daughter of George Villiers, 1st Duke of Buckingham on 3 August 1637.

title: James Stewart, 1st Duke of Richmond
text: A third cousin of Charles I of England, Stewart was a Privy Councillor and key member of Royalist party in the English Civil War.

title: James Stewart, 1st Duke of Richmond
text: In 1641 – 42, he served as Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports.

title: James Stewart, 1st Duke of Richmond
text: He spent five months in exile in 1643, returning to England to defend the city of Oxford for the king.

title: James Stewart, 1st Duke of Richmond
text: He died on 30 March 1655 at age 42 and was buried in Westminster Abbey.

title: Charles Gordon-Lennox, 8th Duke of Richmond
text: Charles Henry Gordon- Lennox, 8th Duke of Richmond, 8th Duke of Lennox, 3rd Duke of Gordon,( 30 December 1870 – 7 May 1935), known as Lord Settrington 1870 – 1903, and as Earl of March 1903 – 1928, was a British Peer and politician.

title: O Valencia!

title: Gabrielle (singer)
text: Known for her ptosis, the drooping of one eyelid, she released her debut single "Dreams" in 1993 and it topped the UK Singles Chart the same year.

title: Gabrielle (singer)
text: Her other singles include "Going NowhereGive Me a Little More TimeWalk On By" and "If You Ever" – a duet with East 17.

title: Gabrielle (singer)

title: Gabrielle (singer)
text: Gabrielle's greatest hits collection, "Dreams Can Come True, Greatest Hits Vol.

title: Gabrielle (singer)
text: 1" was released in 2001.

text: She was the singer of the German band, with whom she released five Albums.

title: Astrid North
text: As guest singer of the band she published three albums.

title: Bernie Bonvoisin
text: Bernard Bonvoisin, known as Bernie Bonvoisin( born 9 July 1956 in Nanterre, Hauts- de- Seine), is a French hard rock singer and film director.

text: He was one of the best friends of Bon Scott the singer of AC/ DC and together they recorded the song" Ride On" which was one of the last songs by Bon Scott.

text: Kristian Leontiou (born February 1982) is a British singer of Greek Cypriot descent, and is the singer for the indie rock band One eskimO.

text: Caspar Babypants is the stage name of children's music artist Chris Ballew, who is also widely known as the singer of The Presidents of the United States of America.

title: Alvin for President
text: " Alvin for President" is a non-album single by the fictional musical group, Alvin and the Chipmunks.

title: Alvin for President
text: The song was released as a single in 1960 and was the group's last chart entry on the" Billboard" Pop Singles Chart.

title: Alvin for President
text: This recording used the same music bed as another song," I Wish I Could Speak French".

title: Alvin for President
text: The song was eventually adapted as a musical sequence on" The Alvin Show" the following year.

title: I Wish (Gabrielle song)
text: "I Wish" is a song by English singer Gabrielle.

title: I Wish (Gabrielle song)
text: It was written by Gabrielle and Jon Douglas for her debut album "

title: I Wish (Gabrielle song)
text: Find Your Way" (1993), while production was helmed by Douglas.

title: I Wish (Gabrielle song)
text: Released as the album's third single, the song was not as successful as its predecessors "Dreams" and "Going Nowhere", which both reached the top ten of the UK Singles Chart, peaking at number 26.

title: I Wish (Gabrielle song)
text: In North America, "I Wish" reached number 52 in the United States and number 76 in Canada.

title: Pema Tseden

title: Pema Tseden
text: He is a member of the China Film Directors' Guild, China Film Association and Chinese Film Literature Association.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Etan Boritzer( born 1950) is an American writer of children ’s literature who is best known for his book" What is God?" first published in 1989.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer gained national critical acclaim after" What is God?" was published in 1989 although the book has caused controversy from religious fundamentalists for its universalist views.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: The other current books in the" What is?" series include

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Love?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Death?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Beautiful?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Funny?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Money?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Dreaming?,

title: Etan Boritzer

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is True?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is a Family?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is a Feeling?"

title: Etan Boritzer
text: The series is now also translated into 15 languages.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer was first published in 1963 at the age of 13 when he wrote an essay in his English class at Wade Junior High School in the Bronx, New York on the assassination of John F. Kennedy.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: His essay was included in a special anthology by New York City public school children compiled and published by the New York City Department of Education.

title: Etan Boritzer

title: Sennedjem
text: The Ancient Egyptian artisan Sennedjem lived in Set Maat( translated as" The Place of Truth"), contemporary Deir el- Medina, on the west bank of the Nile, opposite Thebes, during the reigns of Seti I and Ramesses II.

title: Sennedjem
text: Sennedjem had the title" Servant in the Place of Truth".

title: Sennedjem
text: He was buried along with his wife, Iyneferti, and family in a tomb in the village necropolis.

title: Sennedjem
text: His tomb was discovered January 31, 1886.

title: Sennedjem
text: When Sennedjem's tomb was found, in it there was regular furniture from his home, including a stool and a bed, which he actually used when he was alive.

title: Sennedjem
text: His titles included Servant in the Place of Truth, meaning that he worked on the excavation and decoration of the nearby royal tombs.

title: Place of birth
text: The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.

title: Place of birth
text: This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.

title: Place of birth
text: As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.

title: Place of birth
text: The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.

title: Place of birth
text: If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.

title: Place of birth
text: For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.

title: Place of birth
text: This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.

title: Place of birth
text: Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).

title: Place of birth
text: A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.

title: Place of birth
text: A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.

title: Place of birth
text: In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".

title: Place of birth
text: Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").

title: Place of birth
text: There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.

title: Place of birth
text: The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).

title: Place of birth
text: Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".

title: Place of birth
text: It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".

title: Place of birth
text: For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

title: Motherland (disambiguation)
text: Motherland is the place of one's birth, the place of one's ancestors, or the place of origin of an ethnic group.

title: Motherland (disambiguation)

title: Place of origin

title: Henry St John, 18th Baron St John of Bletso
text: Henry Beauchamp Oliver St John, 18th Baron St John of Bletso DL (24 June 1876 – 17 October 1920) was an English peer.

text: He was the eldest son of Beauchamp St John, 17th Baron St John of Bletso, and his wife Helen Thornton.

text: He was educated at Wellington College and Magdalene College, Cambridge.

text: On 26 July 1901, he was made a Deputy Lieutenant of Bedfordshire.

text: Henry became the 17th Lord St John on the death of his father in 1912, and inherited Melchbourne Park.

text: He was a JP for Bedfordshire and described as Church of England Conservative.

text: He owned about and gave his interests as county pursuits and county business.

title: John St John, 12th Baron St John of Bletso
text: St John was the eldest son of John St John, 11th Baron St John of Bletso and his wife Elizabeth Crowley, daughter of Sir Ambrose Crowley of Greenwich.

title: John St John, 12th Baron St John of Bletso

title: Oliver St John, 3rd Baron St John of Bletso
text: Oliver St John, 3rd Baron St John of Bletso( c. 1540–1618) was an English politician who sat in the House of Commons from 1588 until 1596 when he inherited the peerage as Baron St John of Bletso.

title: Oliver St John, 3rd Baron St John of Bletso
text: St John was a son of Oliver St John, 1st Baron St John of Bletso, and Agnes Fisher.

title: Oliver St John, 3rd Baron St John of Bletso
text: He was High Sheriff of Bedfordshire in 1585.

title: Oliver St John, 3rd Baron St John of Bletso
text: In 1588 he was elected Member of Parliament for Bedfordshire.

title: Oliver St John, 3rd Baron St John of Bletso
text: He was High Sheriff of Bedfordshire again in 1589 and was re-elected MP for Bedfordshire in 1593.

title: Oliver St John, 3rd Baron St John of Bletso
text: He succeeded to the barony on the death of his brother John without male issue on 23 October 1596.

title: Oliver St John, 3rd Baron St John of Bletso
text: He was Lord Lieutenant of Huntingdonshire from April 1597 until his death.

title: Oliver St John, 3rd Baron St John of Bletso
text: St John married Dorothy Reid, daughter of Sir John Rede or Reid, of Odington, Gloucestershire.

title: Oliver St John, 3rd Baron St John of Bletso
text: They had eight sons and seven daughters:

title: Oliver St John, 3rd Baron St John of Bletso
text: His eldest son Oliver inherited the Barony and became Earl of Bolingbroke.

title: Oliver St John, 3rd Baron St John of Bletso
text: Of his remaining sons, John and Dudley died young, while the remaining five all became Members of Parliament.

title: Beauchamp St John, 17th Baron St John of Bletso
text: Beauchamp Moubray St John, 17th Baron St John of Bletso (4 December 1844 – 10 May 1912) was an English peer.

title: Beauchamp St John, 17th Baron St John of Bletso
text: St John was born at Melchbourne, the second son of St Andrew St John, 15th Baron St John of Bletso and his wife Eleanor Hussey.

title: Beauchamp St John, 17th Baron St John of Bletso
text: He served in the Highland Light Infantry until 1867.

title: Beauchamp St John, 17th Baron St John of Bletso
text: He inherited the title Baron St John of Bletso on the death of his brother in 1887 without male heir to become the 17th Baron, and moved to Melchbourne Park, Bedfordshire.

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
text: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford (12 April 155024 June 1604) was an English peer and courtier of the Elizabethan era.

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
text: Oxford was heir to the second oldest earldom in the kingdom, a court favourite for a time, a sought-after patron of the arts, and noted by his contemporaries as a lyric poet and court playwright, but his volatile temperament precluded him from attaining any courtly or governmental responsibility and contributed to the dissipation of his estate.

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
text: Since the 1920s he has been among the most popular alternative candidates proposed for the authorship of Shakespeare's works.

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
text: De Vere was the only son of John de Vere, 16th Earl of Oxford, and Margery Golding.

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
text: After the death of his father in 1562, he became a ward of Queen Elizabeth and was sent to live in the household of her principal advisor, Sir William Cecil.

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
text: He married Cecil's daughter, Anne, with whom he had five children.

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
text: De Vere was estranged from her for five years after he refused to acknowledge her first child as his.

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
text: De Vere was a champion jouster and travelled widely throughout Italy and France.

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
text: He was among the first to compose love poetry at the Elizabethan court, and he was praised as a playwright,

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
text: though none of the plays known as his survive.

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
text: A stream of dedications praised de Vere for his generous patronage of literary, religious, musical, and medical works, and he patronised both adult and boy acting companies, as well as musicians, tumblers, acrobats and performing animals.

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
text: He fell out of favour with the Queen in the early 1580s and was exiled from court after impregnating one of her maids of honour, Anne Vavasour, which instigated violent street brawls between de Vere's retainers and her uncles.

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
text: De Vere was reconciled to the Queen in 1583, but all opportunities for advancement had been lost.

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
text: In 1586, the Queen granted de Vere a £1,000 annuity to relieve his financial distress caused by his extravagance and selling off his income-producing lands for ready money.

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
text: After his wife's death, he married Elizabeth Trentham, one of the Queen's maids of honour, with whom he had an heir, Henry de Vere.

title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford

text: Alexander Carl Otto Westphal (18 May 1863, Berlin – 9 January 1941, Bonn) was a German neurologist and psychiatrist.

title: Alexander Carl Otto Westphal
text: He was the son of the psychiatrist Carl Friedrich Otto Westphal (1833–1890) and Clara Mendelssohn and the grandson of Otto Carl Friedrich Westphal.

title: Alexander Carl Otto Westphal
text: Alexander Westphal studied at Heidelberg and Berlin, receiving his doctorate at Berlin in 1888.

title: Alexander Carl Otto Westphal
text: He then became an assistant to Wilhelm Heinrich Erb (1840-1921) in Heidelberg and to Heinrich Curschmann (1846-1910) in Leipzig.

title: Alexander Carl Otto Westphal
text: In 1892 he became the head physician of the department for nervous diseases at the Berlin Charité under Friedrich Jolly (1844-1904), subsequently qualifying in the fields psychiatry and neurology (1894).

title: Alexander Carl Otto Westphal
text: In 1902 he accepted an invitation to the University of Greifswald as an associate professor, and two years later relocated to the University of Bonn as full professor.

title: Alexander Carl Otto Westphal
text: Westphal made contributions towards the literature involving diabetes insipidus, leukaemia and pseudoleukaemia, as well as a variety of topics in psychiatry and neurology.

title: Alexander Carl Otto Westphal
text: He is eponymously associated with the "Westphal-Pilcz sign" (neurotonic pupillary reaction), a medical indicator named in conjunction with Polish neurologist Jan Pilcz (1870-1931).

title: Alexander Carl Otto Westphal
text: He also produced a compilation of a complete edition of his father's scientific works.

title: Otto Carl Friedrich Westphal

title: Place of birth
text: The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.

title: Place of birth
text: This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.

title: Place of birth
text: As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.

title: Place of birth
text: The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.

title: Place of birth
text: If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.

title: Place of birth
text: For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.

title: Place of birth
text: This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.

title: Place of birth
text: Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).

title: Place of birth
text: A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.

title: Place of birth
text: A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.

title: Place of birth
text: In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".

title: Place of birth
text: Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").

title: Place of birth
text: There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.

title: Place of birth
text: The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).

title: Place of birth
text: Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".

title: Place of birth
text: It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".

title: Place of birth
text: For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

title: Taddea Malaspina
text: Taddea Malaspina( 1505-?) was an Italian marchesa.

title: Taddea Malaspina
text: She was the mistress of Alessandro de' Medici, Duke of Florence from the early 1530s to about 1537 and was likely the mother of at least two of his children, Giulio di Alessandro de' Medici and Giulia de' Medici.

title: Taddea Malaspina
text: Giulio de' Medici was associated with the Malaspina family at different points throughout his life.

title: Taddea Malaspina
text: Taddea was the younger daughter of Alberico Malaspina, sovereign marquis of Massa, and Lucrezia d' Este.

title: Taddea Malaspina
text: She married Count Giambattista Boiardo di Scandiano.

title: Taddea Malaspina
text: After his death and the death of her father, Malaspina lived with her mother in Florence and had a number of lovers, including Alessandro.

title: Taddea Malaspina
text: Her sister Ricciarda inherited the title after their father's death.

title: Taddea Malaspina
text: Through Ricciarda's marriage, the family was related to Pope Innocent VIII.

title: Taddea Malaspina
text: Ricciarda was probably also one of Alessandro de' Medici's lovers.

title: Taddea Malaspina
text: In a portrait of Alessandro by Pontormo, dated to about 1534, the Duke, dressed in black, draws the profile of a woman in silverpoint.

title: Taddea Malaspina
text: The portrait may have been a gift for Malaspina.

title: Taddea Malaspina
text: The Chiesa della Madonna del Carmine and the Santa Chiara monastic complex in Massa, now in the Italian province of Massa Carrara, were built on Taddea Malaspina's order; they still stand.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: Catherine de' Medici (13 April 1519 – 5 January 1589), was an Italian noblewoman who was queen consort of France from 1547 until 1559, by marriage to King Henry II, and Queen mother of kings Francis II, Charles IX and Henry III from 1559 to 1589.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: The years during which her sons reigned have been called "the age of Catherine de' Medici" as she had extensive, if at times varying, influence in the political life of France.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: She was born in Florence to Lorenzo de’ Medici, Duke of Urbino and Madeleine de La Tour d'Auvergne.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: In 1533, at the age of fourteen, Catherine married Henry, second son of King Francis I and Queen Claude of France.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: Catherine's marriage was arranged by her uncle Pope Clement VII.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: Henry excluded Catherine from participating in state affairs and instead showered favors on his chief mistress, Diane de Poitiers, who wielded much influence over him.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: Henry's death thrust Catherine into the political arena as mother of the frail 15-year-old King Francis II.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: When he died in 1560, she became regent on behalf of her 10-year-old son King Charles IX and was granted sweeping powers.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: From 1560 to 1563, she ruled France as regent for her son Charles IX, King of France.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: After Charles died in 1574, Catherine played a key role in the reign of her third son, Henry III.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: He dispensed with her advice only in the last months of her life (he would outlive her by seven months).

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: Catherine's three sons reigned in an age of almost constant civil and religious war in France.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: The problems facing the monarchy were complex and daunting but Catherine was able to keep the monarchy and the state institutions functioning even at a minimum level.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: At first, Catherine compromised and made concessions to the rebelling Calvinist Protestants, or Huguenots, as they became known.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: She failed, however, to grasp the theological issues that drove their movement.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: Later she resorted, in frustration and anger, to hard-line policies against them.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: In return, she came to be blamed for the excessive persecutions carried out under her sons' rule, in particular for the St. Bartholomew's Day massacre of 1572, in which thousands of Huguenots were killed in Paris and throughout France.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: Some historians have excused Catherine from blame for the worst decisions of the crown, though evidence for her ruthlessness can be found in her letters.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: In practice, her authority was always limited by the effects of the civil wars.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: Her policies, therefore, may be seen as desperate measures to keep the Valois monarchy on the throne at all costs, and her patronage of the arts as an attempt to glorify a monarchy whose prestige was in steep decline.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: Without Catherine, it is unlikely that her sons would have remained in power.

title: Catherine de' Medici
text: According to Mark Strage, one of her biographers, Catherine was the most powerful woman in 16th-century Europe.

title: Francis II of France
text: Francis II (19 January 1544 – 5 December 1560) was King of France from 1559 to 1560.

title: Francis II of France
text: He was also King consort of Scotland as a result of his marriage to Mary, Queen of Scots, from 1558 until his death in 1560.

title: Francis II of France
text: He ascended the throne of France at the age of fifteen after the accidental death of his father, Henry II, in 1559.

title: Francis II of France
text: His short reign was dominated by the first stirrings of the French Wars of Religion.

title: Francis II of France
text: Although the royal age of majority had been set at fourteen, his mother, Catherine de' Medici, entrusted the reins of government to his wife's uncles from the House of Guise, staunch supporters of the Catholic cause.

title: Francis II of France
text: They were unable to help Catholics in Scotland against the progressing Scottish Reformation, however, and the Auld Alliance was dissolved.

title: Francis II of France
text: Francis was succeeded by two of his brothers in turn, both of whom were also unable to reduce tensions between Protestants and Catholics.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: John Frank Dalton( March 8, 1848 August 15, 1951) was a man who, in the last few years( 1948- 1951) of his long life, publicly claimed to be the famous outlaw Jesse James.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: However, most professional historians believe that Dalton was merely a Jesse James impostor, and that the real Jesse James was killed by Robert" Bob" Ford on April 3, 1882, in a house Jesse was renting located at 1318 Lafayette Street in St. Joseph, Missouri.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: With the death of Jesse James in 1882, and the subsequent death of his( Dalton's) wife Julia Ellen Groshon during childbirth in 1886, Dalton abandoned his children and began roaming the countryside.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: In the 1930s and 1940s he appeared in Independence County, Arkansas, telling tales of being Jesse James, and on other occasions he told tales of being the famous Western lawman John Franklin" Frank" Dalton( June 8, 1859- November 27, 1887), thus earning himself a meal.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: By the 1940s he was in Oklahoma and Texas, where his uncle lived and he had relatives.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: It was in Texas that he first claimed he was the same Frank Dalton who historians believe had been killed in 1887.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: When it was proved that he was n't the original Frank Dalton( 1859- 1887), in April, 1948- in Lawton, Oklahoma- he took up being Jesse James instead.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: Dalton was allegedly 100 years old at the time of his first public appearance as Jesse James- at Lawton, Oklahoma in April – May, 1948.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: Like the real Jesse James, Dalton apparently had been a pro-Confederate guerrilla in Missouri during the Civil War.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: However, Dalton's account of himself as Jesse James did not hold up under questioning from Jesse James' surviving relatives.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: Nevertheless, several people of note, such as journalist/ novelist Robert Ruark, were convinced that J. Frank Dalton was the famous outlaw Jesse Woodson James.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: To many people's surprise, Dalton did appear to have many of the unique body marks/ body features which the real Jesse James was rumored to have.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: These body features included: seven bullet wounds, a rope burn around his neck, a collapsed lung, a damaged fingertip, and severely burned feet.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: On September 5, 1949, Rudi Turilli and Lester B. Dill( the general manager and owner, respectively, of Meramec Caverns, near Stanton, Missouri) hosted a reunion at Meramec Caverns for Dalton and his last- remaining old- time friends, in celebration of Dalton's/ Jesse James' supposed 102nd birthday.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: J. Frank Dalton died on August 15, 1951, in Granbury, Texas, and his death certificate was recorded with the name of the man he claimed to be.

title: J. Frank Dalton
text: His gravestone in Granbury Cemetery also has that claimed identity recorded on it.

title: David Lean
text: Sir David Lean (25 March 190816 April 1991) was an English film director, producer, screenwriter and editor.

title: David Lean
text: Widely considered as one of the most influential directors of all time, Lean was mostly famous for his large-scale epics such as "The Bridge on the River Kwai" (1957), "Lawrence of Arabia" (1962), "Doctor Zhivago" (1965) and "A Passage to India" (1984).

title: David Lean
text: He also directed adaptations of Charles Dickens novels "Great Expectations" (1946) and "Oliver Twist" (1948), and the romantic drama "Brief Encounter" (1945).

title: David Lean
text: Originally a film editor in the early 1930s, Lean made his directorial debut with 1942's "In Which We Serve", which was the first of four collaborations with Noël Coward.

title: David Lean
text: Beginning with "Summertime" in 1955, Lean began to make internationally co-produced films financed by the big Hollywood studios; in 1970, however, the critical failure of his film "Ryan's Daughter" led him to take a fourteen-year break from filmmaking, during which he planned a number of film projects which never came to fruition.

title: David Lean
text: In 1984 he had a career revival with "A Passage to India", adapted from E. M. Forster's novel; it was an instant hit with critics but proved to be the last film Lean would direct.

title: David Lean
text: Lean's affinity for pictorialism and inventive editing techniques has led him to be lauded by directors such as Steven Spielberg, Stanley Kubrick, Martin Scorsese, and Ridley Scott.

title: David Lean
text: Lean was voted 9th greatest film director of all time in the British Film Institute "Sight & SoundDirectors' Top Directors" poll in 2002.

title: David Lean
text: Nominated seven times for the Academy Award for Best Director, which he won twice for "The Bridge on the River Kwai" and "Lawrence of Arabia", he has seven films in the British Film Institute's Top 100 British Films (with three of them being in the top five) and was awarded the AFI Life Achievement Award in 1990.

title: Gourmaëlon
text: Gourmaëlon or Wrmaelon( died 913/ 4), was the Count of Cornouaille and" de facto" ruler of Brittany from 907 – c. 914.

title: Gourmaëlon
text: As ruler of Brittany he was considered" Prince de Bretagne" in some chronicles and histories.

title: Gourmaëlon
text: His actual history is among the least well documented of the early medieval rulers of Brittany.

title: Gourmaëlon
text: His reputed time of rule coincides with a dramatic increase in Viking invasions that ultimately led up to the Viking Occupation of Brittany that began after his death.

title: Gourmaëlon
text: He is believed to have been named Count of Cornouaille by Alan I, King of Brittany near the end of his reign in 907.

title: Gourmaëlon
text: After Alan I's death in 907 he disputed the right of Alan's heirs to rule Brittany and fought for the control of the kingdom, albeit without claiming the title king.

title: Gourmaëlon
text: His life and activities are sparsely recorded in historical documents save for several donations to the Breton churches of the day.

title: Gourmaëlon
text: In a donation to the monastery of Plélan in 910 he is identified as ruler of Brittany.

title: Gourmaëlon
text: At Redon in 913 he is identified as" Count Gourmaelon, the Breton monarch."

title: Gourmaëlon
text: He is understood to have died in 913( or 914) in a battle with invading Vikings.

title: Gourmaëlon
text: No subsequent ruler of Brittany is recorded in histories or chronicles of the period until the return of Alan II, Duke of Brittany, known as Alan Barbetorte, from England c. 937–938.

title: Bertha of Blois

title: Bertha of Blois
text: She was the daughter of Odo II, Count of Blois and Ermengarde of Auvergne.

title: Françoise de Dinan
text: Françoise de Dinan( 1436- 1499), was a French heiress, courtier and educator.

title: Françoise de Dinan
text: She was the governess of Anne of Brittany.

title: Françoise de Dinan
text: She was the daughter and heir of Jacques de Dinan( d. 1444), lord of Beaumanoir and chamberlain at the court of Brittany, and Catherine de Rohan.

title: Françoise de Dinan
text: Sh was also the heir of her paternal uncle Bertrand de Dinan( d. 1444), Marshall of Bretagne, Lord of Montafilant, Chateaubriant and Huguetières.

title: Françoise de Dinan
text: She was abducted by and forced to marry Gilles of Brittany, brother of Francis I, Duke of Brittany and Peter II, Duke of Brittany, in 1444.

title: Françoise de Dinan
text: She was widowed in 1450, when her spouse was imprisoned and died on the instigation of Arthur de Montauban, who wished to marry her.

title: Françoise de Dinan
text: By the help of Françoise d'Amboise, she married Guy XIV de Laval in 1451.

title: Françoise de Dinan
text: In 1488, she was appointed governess to Anne of Brittany and her sister Isabelle.

title: Françoise de Dinan
text: She played an active role on the political marriage arrangements surrounding Anne.

title: Françoise de Dinan
text: In 1494, she remarried the noble Jean de Proisy.

title: Eiludd Powys
text: Eiludd Powys was an early 7th-century King of Powys.

title: Eiludd Powys
text: One theory asserts that when Manwgan ap Selyf came to the throne in 613 he was a young boy, which led to an invasion of Powys by Eluadd ap Glast

title: Eiludd Powys
text: (alias Eiludd Powys), the erstwhile King of Dogfeiling.

title: Eiludd Powys
text: The usurper probably managed to hold the throne for some thirty years or more before he was killed fighting the Northumbrians, possibly at the Battle of Maes Cogwy (Oswestry) in 642.

title: Eiludd Powys
text: The Dogfeiling dynasty was finally crushed by the Saxons around 656.

title: Eiludd Powys
text: He was more likely the son or younger brother of Selyf "Sarffgadau" ap Cynan Garwyn.

title: Eiludd Powys
text: It is not known which he is as there are two accounts one in the Jesus College Ms.20

title: Eiludd Powys
text: that makes him the son of Selyf and brother of Manwgan whereas the Harleian Ms. 3859 makes him the brother of Selyf Sarffgadau, he could be either as it is not unheard of that a brother succeeds in absence of a mature heir (see Rhyddfedd Frych), as well as the eldest being overlooked as successor by their father

title: Eiludd Powys
text: (see Gruffydd ap Llywelyn Fawr and Dafydd ap Llywelyn).

title: Eiludd Powys
text: But what is interesting is a reference to the descendants of Selyf, serpents of Battle by the Powysian Court Poet Cynddelw Brydydd Mawr and that he specifically during this time of the 12th Century worked for the Powysian Royal family and then after their fall, went to work under Gwynedd and then later Powys Wenwynwyn.

title: Beli ap Eiludd
text: Beli ap Eiludd was a 7th- century King of Powys.

title: Beli ap Eiludd
text: Some theories assert that he was in fact the son of Manwgan ap Selyf who regained power after Eiludd Powys was killed at the battle of Battle of Maes Cogwy in 642.

title: Beli ap Eiludd
text: It is more likely however that as the genealogies state he was the son of Eiludd who was either the son or brother of Selyf, the former being the most likely due to a surviving reference from Cynddelw painting the Mathrafal dynasty as being descendants of Selyf.

title: Beli ap Eiludd
text: It was also likely if Eiludd Powys fought at Maes Cogwy alongside Elfan Powys and Cynddylan, Beli would have been the King whom Heledd ran to for protection.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: The Free Expression Tunnel is the longest, widest, and most heavily used pedestrian tunnel under the railroad tracks at North Carolina State University in Raleigh, North Carolina (also goes under Yarbrough Drive).

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: The special aspect of the tunnel is that anyone is permitted to decorate its walls, ceiling, and floor.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: The tunnel connects NCSU's North Campus with the Central Campus and provides the most direct route from The Brickyard to the Central Campus residence halls.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: Clubs, fraternities, sororities, and other organizations often paint the tunnel to promote events and amateur artists paint to express themselves and to promote freedom of speech.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: A retaining wall just outside the tunnel's south entrance is also open for free expression.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: The "service tunnel" itself was constructed in 1939 as a Public Works Administration project.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: The tunnel was first painted in 1968, when it was painted red and white to celebrate the military veterans of North Carolina

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: Fans of other universities' sports teams often come to the Free Expression Tunnel before and sometimes after big athletic events to paint the tunnel with their teams' athletic colors as part of a prank.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: Carolina Tar Heel fans have a long history of doing this prank as well as fans from East Carolina University.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: The tunnel is subject to flooding during massive torrential rains.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: Waters rose to a height of 60 inches after a storm in July 2003.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: For the Spring 2005-2006 semester, the Free Expression Tunnel was closed for repairs and the installation of handicap ramps.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: The tunnel reopened in the winter of 2006 with a re-dedication ceremony, which unveiled a new plaque at the tunnel's north entrance expressing the brief history of the tunnel and its purpose.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: Prior to the renovations, the space available for free expression was much larger at both ends.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: On November 5, 2008 racist, threatening graffiti directed at (then) President-elect Barack Obama was found in the tunnel.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: Because of the threats against Obama, the Secret Service was among those called to investigate.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: The four students responsible were identified, and admitted to the act, stating that it was protected by their First Amendment right to free speech; however the North Carolina chapter of the NAACP has called for their expulsion.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: Since February 2010, there has been an ongoing tradition of a weekly freestyle cypher, every Monday night around 11pm.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: Local artists and students alike gather at the tunnel to freestyle, beatbox, sing, play instruments, recite poetry, and network.

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: More photos of the tunnel and the free expression art can be seen at the tunnel's Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/FreeX.NCSU

title: Free Expression Tunnel
text: The video below is an example of what people can do in the tunnel.

title: Black Rock Tunnel
text: The Black Rock Tunnel is an active rail road tunnel of the old Reading Railroad.

title: Black Rock Tunnel
text: The 1835 tunnel was the third rail tunnel constructed in the United States, and is the third oldest still in use.

title: Black Rock Tunnel
text: The tunnel is also notable as being the first for which shafts were sunk during construction.

title: Black Rock Tunnel
text: The tunnel is cut through a hill in Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States.

title: Black Rock Tunnel
text: The tunnel and line are now owned by Norfolk Southern as part of its Harrisburg Line.

title: Black Rock Tunnel
text: The Black Rock Tunnel was constructed between 1835 and 1837 and opened in 1838.

title: Black Rock Tunnel
text: W. Hasell Wilson was the resident engineer in charge.

title: Black Rock Tunnel
text: The tunnel was originally long, wide, and high.

title: Black Rock Tunnel
text: The tunnel passes below the top of the hill.

title: Black Rock Tunnel
text: A then- unique feature of the tunnel's construction was the sinking of six, diameter shafts, tangent to the tunnel cross section.

title: Black Rock Tunnel
text: These shafts were spaced at intervals to correct errors in the tunnel alignment.

title: Black Rock Tunnel
text: Construction of the tunnel cost an estimated$ 178,992.

title: Black Rock Tunnel
text: Noted local miner, geologist and palaentologist Charles M. Wheatley examined the rock excavated from the tunnel and identified many previously unknown fossilized species, some of which now bear his name.

text: He was Spanish ambassador in London and Rome.

title: Íñigo Vélez de Guevara, 8th Count of Oñate
text: He later served as viceroy of the Kingdom of Naples (from 1648) (see List of Spanish Viceroys of Naples), where he repulsed a French attack during the Franco-Spanish War (1635).
