text: Somerset obtained Tintern Abbey after the Dissolution of the Monasteries.

title: Henry Somerset, 2nd Earl of Worcester
text: He married twice:

title: Richard Beauchamp, 1st Earl of Worcester
text: Richard de Beauchamp, 1st Earl of Worcester, KCB (c. 1394 – c. 18 March 1421/1422) was an English peer.

title: Richard Beauchamp, 1st Earl of Worcester
text: The only son of William de Beauchamp, 1st Baron Bergavenny, he succeeded as 2nd Baron Bergavenny at the death of his father on 8 May 1411.

title: Richard Beauchamp, 1st Earl of Worcester
text: On 27 July 1411, he married Lady Isabel le Despenser, daughter of Thomas le Despenser, 1st Earl of Gloucester, and great-granddaughter of Edward III.

title: Richard Beauchamp, 1st Earl of Worcester
text: They had one child, Lady Elizabeth de Beauchamp, later 3rd Baroness Bergavenny, who married Sir Edward Neville, later 1st Baron Bergavenny.

title: Richard Beauchamp, 1st Earl of Worcester
text: He was joint Warden of the Welsh Marches in 1415, and a captain of lances and archers in Normandy in 1418.

title: Richard Beauchamp, 1st Earl of Worcester
text: In February 1420/1, he was created Earl of Worcester.

title: Richard Beauchamp, 1st Earl of Worcester
text: Worcester was mortally wounded on 18 March 1421/2 at the Siege of Meaux and died soon after.

title: Richard Beauchamp, 1st Earl of Worcester
text: His body was taken back to England and he was buried on 25 April 1422 at Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire.

title: Richard Beauchamp, 1st Earl of Worcester
text: His daughter inherited his estates and his barony of Bergavenny, although the castle and honour of Abergavenny were still held by her grandmother in dower.

title: Joan FitzAlan, Baroness Bergavenny
text: Joan de Beauchamp, Baroness Bergavenny( née FitzAlan; 1375 – 14 November 1435) was an English noblewoman, and the wife of William de Beauchamp, 1st Baron Bergavenny of the Welsh Marches.

title: Philippa de Beauchamp

title: Philippa de Beauchamp
text: On or before 1 March 1350 she married Hugh de Stafford, 2nd Earl of Stafford, son of Ralph de Stafford, 1st Earl of Stafford and Margaret Audley, Baroness Audley.

title: Philippa de Beauchamp
text: Philippa and Hugh had seven children.

title: Richard (III), bishop of Bayeux

text: Beauchamp was the fourth son of Thomas de Beauchamp, 11th Earl of Warwick, and Katherine Mortimer.

title: William Beauchamp, 1st Baron Bergavenny

title: William Beauchamp, 1st Baron Bergavenny
text: Upon the death of his first cousin once removed, John Hastings, 3rd Earl of Pembroke on 30 December 1389, William inherited the lordship of Abergavenny, including Abergavenny Castle.

title: William Beauchamp, 1st Baron Bergavenny
text: He was summoned to Parliament on 23 July 1392 as "Willilmo Beauchamp de Bergavenny", by which he is held to have become Baron Bergavenny, a barony by writ.

title: William Beauchamp, 1st Baron Bergavenny
text: In 1399, he was appointed Justiciar of South Wales and Governor of Pembroke.

title: William Beauchamp, 1st Baron Bergavenny
text: He entailed the castle and Honour of Abergavenny on the issue male of his body, with remainder to his brother Thomas de Beauchamp, 12th Earl of Warwick and his heirs male; his wife enjoyed it in dower until her death in 1435.

text: From 13 November 1750 to 1766 he was the Captain- General of the Netherlands, where he was known as the Duke of Brunswick or( to distinguish him from his eldest brother Charles, who succeeded to their father's title of Duke of Brunswick- Lüneburg) Duke of Brunswick- Wolfenbüttel.

title: Augustus William Lumley-Savile
text: Augustus William Lumley- Savile, renamed Augustus William Savile in 1881,( 1829, London – 13 April 1887, Cannes) was an English landowner and Her Majesty's Assistant Master of the Ceremonies.

title: Augustus William Lumley-Savile
text: John Lumley- Savile, 8th Earl of Scarbrough was Augustus William Lumley- Savile's father.

title: Augustus William Lumley-Savile
text: Lord Scarbrough never married but engendered five natural children, four sons and one daughter.

title: Augustus William Lumley-Savile
text: The earl bequeathed the family estates to his second son Captain Henry Lumley( d. 1881), and on Captain Lumley's death the estates passed to Augustus William Lumley- Savile, who was the youngest of the four sons.

title: Augustus William Lumley-Savile
text: In 1883 the family estates consisted of 17,820 acres in Nottinghamshire and 16,000 acres in the West Riding of Yorkshire.

title: Augustus William Lumley-Savile
text: The principal residence was Rufford Abbey, near Ollerton.

title: Augustus William Lumley-Savile
text: In 1847 Augustus William Lumley- Saville matriculated at Corpus Christi College, Oxford.

title: Augustus William Lumley-Savile
text: On 23 November 1849 he became a cornet in a cavalry regiment, the 2nd Regiment of Life Guards.

title: Augustus William Lumley-Savile
text: In 1881 by royal licence he dropped the name of Lumley.

title: Augustus William Lumley-Savile
text: He served as Queen Victoria's assistant- master of ceremonies from 1881 until his death.

title: Augustus William Lumley-Savile
text: When Augustus William Savile died in 1887 the family estates were inherited by his brother John Lumley- Savile, who assumed the surname of Savile only.

title: Augustus William, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg
text: Augustus William( 8 March 1662 – 23 March 1731), a member of the House of Welf, was Duke of Brunswick- Lüneburg and ruling Prince of Wolfenbüttel from 1714 until his death.

title: William, Duke of Brunswick
text: William, Duke of Brunswick( 25 April 1806 – 18 October 1884), was ruling duke of the Duchy of Brunswick from 1830 until his death.

title: William, Duke of Brunswick
text: William was the second son of Frederick William, Duke of Brunswick- Lüneburg, and after the death of his father in 1815, was under the guardianship of King George IV of the United Kingdom.

title: William, Duke of Brunswick
text: He became a Prussian major in 1823.

title: William, Duke of Brunswick
text: When his brother, Charles, was deposed as ruling duke by a rebellion in 1830, William took over the government provisionally.

title: William, Duke of Brunswick
text: In 1831, a family law of the House of Guelph made William the ruling duke permanently.

title: William, Duke of Brunswick
text: William left most government business to his ministers, and he spent most of his time outside of his state at his possessions in Oels.

title: William, Duke of Brunswick
text: While William joined the Prussian- led North German Confederation in 1866, his relationship to Prussia was strained, since Prussia refused to recognize Ernest Augustus, Crown Prince of Hanover, his nearest male- line relative, as his heir, because of the Duke of Cumberland's claim to the throne of Hanover.

title: William, Duke of Brunswick
text: William died in 1884; he passed on his private possessions to the Duke of Cumberland.

title: William, Duke of Brunswick
text: His death caused a constitutional crisis for Brunswick that lasted until the accession of Ernest Augustus, Duke of Brunswick, the son of the Crown Prince of Hanover, in 1913.

title: William, Duke of Brunswick
text: William died unmarried, but had a number of illegitimate children.

title: Ernest Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg
text: Ernest Ferdinand of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel-Bevern (4 March 1682 in Osterholz – 14 April 1746 in Brunswick) was a titular Duke of Brunswick and Lüneburg.

title: Ernest Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg
text: He was Prince of Brunswick-Bevern and founder of the younger Brunswick-Bevern line.

title: Charles William Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick
text: Charles William Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg, Prince of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel (9 October 1735 – 10 November 1806) was the Prince of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel and Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg and a military leader.

title: Charles William Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick
text: His titles are usually shortened to Duke of Brunswick in English-language sources.

title: Charles William Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick
text: He succeeded his father as sovereign prince of the Principality of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel, one of the princely states of the Holy Roman Empire.

title: Charles William Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick
text: The duke was a cultured and benevolent despot in the model of Frederick the Great, and was married to Princess Augusta, a sister of George III of Great Britain.

title: Charles William Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick
text: He was also a recognized master of 18th century warfare, serving as a Field Marshal in the Prussian Army.

title: Charles William Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick
text: During the Napoleonic Wars, he was mortally wounded by a musket ball at the Battle of Jena–Auerstedt in 1806.

title: Augustus William, Duke of Brunswick-Bevern
text: August Wilhelm, Duke of Brunswick-Bevern (1715 in Braunschweig1781 in Stettin), Prussian soldier, son of Ernest Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg, was born in Braunschweig in 1715, and entered the Prussian army in 1731, becoming colonel of an infantry regiment in 1739.

title: Augustus William, Duke of Brunswick-Bevern
text: He won great distinction at the battle of Hohenfriedberg as a major-general, and was promoted lieutenant-general in 1750.

title: Augustus William, Duke of Brunswick-Bevern
text: Bevern was one of the most experienced and exact soldiers in the army of Frederick the Great.

title: Augustus William, Duke of Brunswick-Bevern
text: He commanded a wing in the battle of Lobositz in 1756, and defeated the Austrians under Marshal Königsegg in a well-fought battle at Reichenberg on 21 April 1757.

title: Augustus William, Duke of Brunswick-Bevern
text: He took part in the battles of Prague and Kolin and the retreat to Görlitz, and subsequently commanded the Prussians left behind by Frederick in the autumn of 1757 when he marched against the French.

title: Augustus William, Duke of Brunswick-Bevern
text: Bevern conducted a defensive campaign against overwhelming numbers with great skill, but he soon lost the valuable assistance of General Winterfeldt, who was killed in a skirmish at Moys; and he was eventually brought to battle and suffered a heavy defeat at the battle of Breslau on 22 November.

title: Augustus William, Duke of Brunswick-Bevern
text: He fell into the hands of the Austrians on the following morning, and remained prisoner for a year.

title: Augustus William, Duke of Brunswick-Bevern
text: He was made general of infantry in 1759, and on 11 August 1762 inflicted a severe defeat at Reichenbach on an Austrian army endeavouring to relieve Schweidnitz.

title: Augustus William, Duke of Brunswick-Bevern
text: Bevern retired, after the peace of Hubertusburg, to his government of Stettin, where he died in peace in 1781.

title: Frederick William, Duke of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel
text: Frederick William, Duke of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel (9 October 1771 – 16 June 1815) was a German prince and Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg and Oels.

title: Frederick William, Duke of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel
text: Nicknamed "The Black Duke", he was a military officer who led the Black Brunswickers against French domination in Germany.

title: Frederick William, Duke of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel
text: He briefly ruled the state of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel from 1806 to 1807 and again from 1813 to 1815.

title: Caligula
text: Caligula (31 August 12 – 24 January 41 AD) was Roman emperor from 37 to 41 AD.

title: Caligula
text: The son of the popular Roman general Germanicus and Augustus's granddaughter Agrippina the Elder, Caligula was born into the first ruling family of the Roman Empire, conventionally known as the Julio-Claudian dynasty.

title: Caligula
text: Germanicus's uncle and adoptive father, Tiberius, succeeded Augustus as emperor of Rome in 14 AD.

title: Caligula
text: Although he was born Gaius Caesar, after Julius Caesar, he acquired the nickname "Caligula" (

title: Caligula
text: meaning "little  boot", the diminutive form of "caliga") from his father's soldiers during their campaign in Germania.

title: Caligula
text: When Germanicus died at Antioch in 19, Agrippina returned with her six children to Rome, where she became entangled in a bitter feud with Tiberius.

title: Caligula
text: The conflict eventually led to the destruction of her family, with Caligula as the sole male survivor.

title: Caligula
text: Untouched by the deadly intrigues, Caligula accepted an invitation in 31 to join the emperor on the island of Capri, where Tiberius had withdrawn five years earlier.

title: Caligula
text: Following the death of Tiberius, Caligula succeeded his adoptive grandfather as emperor in 37.

title: Caligula
text: There are few surviving sources about the reign of Caligula, although he is described as a noble and moderate emperor during the first six months of his rule.

title: Caligula
text: After this, the sources focus upon his cruelty, sadism, extravagance, and sexual perversion, presenting him as an insane tyrant.

title: Caligula
text: While the reliability of these sources is questionable, it is known that during his brief reign, Caligula worked to increase the unconstrained personal power of the emperor, as opposed to countervailing powers within the principate.

title: Caligula
text: He directed much of his attention to ambitious construction projects and luxurious dwellings for himself, and initiated the construction of two aqueducts in Rome: the Aqua Claudia and the Anio Novus.

title: Caligula
text: During his reign, the empire annexed the client kingdom of Mauretania as a province.

title: Caligula
text: In early 41, Caligula was assassinated as a result of a conspiracy by officers of the Praetorian Guard, senators, and courtiers.

title: Caligula
text: The conspirators' attempt to use the opportunity to restore the Roman Republic was thwarted, however.

title: Caligula
text: On the day of the assassination of Caligula, the Praetorians declared Caligula's uncle, Claudius, the next Roman emperor.

title: Caligula
text: Although the Julio-Claudian dynasty continued to rule the empire until the fall of his nephew Nero in 68, Caligula's death marked the official end of the Julii Caesares in the male line.

title: Gaza Ghetto
text: Gaza Ghetto: Portrait of a Family, 1948 – 1984 is a documentary film about the life of a Palestinian family living in the Jabalia refugee camp.

title: Gaza Ghetto
text: The film, created by Joan Mandell, Pea Holmquist, and Pierre Bjorklund in 1984 is believed to be the first documentary ever made in Gaza.

title: Gaza Ghetto
text: The film features Ariel Sharon, Binyamin Ben-Eliezer and soldiers on patrol" candidly discuss their responsibilities."

title: Gaza Ghetto
text: In his book," An Accented Cinema: Exilic and Diasporic Filmmaking", Hamid Naficy describes the film as an" early important film" on the Palestinian refugee situation.

title: Gaza Ghetto
text: The film follows a refugee family from the Gaza Strip who visit the site of their former village, now a Jewish town in Israel.

title: Gaza Ghetto
text: As the grandfather and great- grandfather point out an orchard and sycamore fig that belonged to Muhammed Ayyub and Uncle Khalil, an Israeli resident appears and tells them to leave, claiming they need a permit to be there.

title: Gaza Ghetto
text: The mother tells him that," We work in Jaffa and Tel Aviv and that's not forbidden," to which he replies," Here it's forbidden."

title: Gaza Ghetto
text: Ted Swedenburg mentions his scene in" Memories of Revolt: The 1936- 1939 Rebellion and the Palestinian National PastWhile chasing the refugee family off, he asserts forcibly that the site is" his" home."

title: Kull the Conqueror
text: Kull the Conqueror is a 1997 fantasy film about the Robert E. Howard character Kull starring Kevin Sorbo.

title: Kull the Conqueror
text: It is a film adaptation of Howard's Conan novel" The Hour of the Dragon", with the protagonist changed to the author's other barbarian hero Kull.

title: Kull the Conqueror
text: The storyline also bears similarities to two other Howard stories, the Kull story" By This Axe I Rule!" and the Conan story" The Phoenix on the Sword", which was actually a rewrite of the Kull story.

title: Kull the Conqueror
text: The film was originally intended to be the third Conan film," Conan the Conqueror".

title: Kull the Conqueror
text: The protagonist was changed due to Arnold Schwarzenegger's refusal to reprise his role as Conan and Sorbo's reluctance to redo a character already played.

title: Kull the Conqueror
text: Screenwriter Charles Edward Pogue has stated that he was extremely displeased with this film, feeling that his script was ruined by studio interference.

title: James B. Harris
text: He also directed the actor James Woods in two films: the prison- guard drama" Fast- Walking"( 1982) with actress Kay Lenz, and the thriller" Cop"( 1988), based on a James Ellroy novel, which Woods co-produced.

title: James B. Harris
text: The Turner Classic Movies website describes Harris as a" veteran Hollywood industry figure who has served triple duty as a producer, director, and screenwriter".

text: A 2002 interview between Harris and Hollywood Five- O includes discussion of his works, of Kubrick, Marlon Brando, Laurence Olivier," Lolita", and of various other topics.
